key_points: Election disinformation dropped dramatically on Twitter and other platforms after Trump was banned.
Zignal found a steep decline in disinformation following the Twitter ban on January 8.
Trump and allies lost accounts on multiple platforms such as Facebook, Instagram, Snapchat, Twitch, Spotify, Shopify.
Twitter's ban was significant in curbing Trump's ability to spread misleading claims about the election.
The ban was part of broader social media actions, including Twitter's ban of over 70,000 QAnon-affiliated accounts.
Use of hashtags affiliated with the Capitol riot also dropped considerably.
De-platforming curbs momentum and ability to reach new audiences but may harden views of those already engaged.
Media Matters for America noted a significant fall in interactions on right-leaning political Facebook pages post-ban.
Few accounts acted as 'superspreaders' of election misinformation, with Trump's account being a major source.
Advance Democracy found a decrease in election fraud claims but violent narratives continue to spread at the peripheries.
spokespersons: Kate Starbird (disinformation researcher, University of Washington)
Graham Brookie (director, Atlantic Council’s Digital Forensic Research Lab)
Leysia Palen (information science professor, University of Colorado)
